body: SNP-SIG: Identification and annotation of SNPs in the context of structure, function, and disease

comments.body:
Highlight Speaker: Mauno Vihinen, Tampere University (Finland) 
Genetic variations: origin, effects and prediction.
Usually we think variations as harmful, while most of them are not
Genome size of gene numbers does not directly correlate with complexity of organism
Less than 5% human genomes codes for proteins, rest just called junk DNA, but it is not, still majority of the genome is expressed
Variations increases the total number of genes and gene products
Total no. of variations in genome is not known
Variation type - chromosome set number variation (euploidy)
and chromosome structure variation
Variations at DNA level - binding site - TFs, promotor, start and stop codons and Genome organisation
at RNA level - most important effects on splice sites, generation of novel splice sites, alt splicing, variation destroying splice sites
at proteins level -- Many ways to affect function # functional sites, sub-cellular localization, stability effects, changes in disorder, aggregation, electrostatic pro, interactions, stearic effects
Large genomes projects
the 1000 genomes project www.1000genomes.org
Genome 10Kproject http://genome10k.org
uk10k http://www.uk10k.org
MyGenome
Data management, storage, analysis, access, ethics, integration with other data is a big challenge, but extremely useful
Human Variome Project www.humanvariomeproject.org
Variome - Variation in a genome
a public catalogue of curated variations in each of 20k genes and associated phenotyes/studies
worldwide agreed standard systems, notations
about 2000 LSDBs exist
HGVS www.hgvs.org
Diseases names - OMIM, ICD10 - www.who.int/classifications/icd/en
Variation nomenclature - www.hgvs.org/
GEN2PHEN project ...pan european effort
Human have 99.9% identical genomes
Genome consists of about 3 billion bases, this means that there are millions of differences, some of them are harmful, but which ones?
how to interpret variations and their effects? NGS and other methods produce very large datasets. Impossible to investigate all cases with experimental approaches
Majority of variations are not harmful, only few are causing dieases
extensive deletions, frameshift variations, nonsense variations and other cases that clearly destroy the function of the gene or product
paper - Thusberg and Vihinen Hum.Mut.2009
Performance analysis - test data sets needed, it should be representative, unbiased, large enough, not used for training, and have systematic description
Benchmark datasets available from "VeriBench", other one Varia ontology (VariO), AmiVario
validated prediction tools  and described in the paper- Thusberg et al. Hum Mutat 2011
Performance of protein localization predictors - Laurila and Vihinen BMC Bioinformatics; Laurila and Vihinen Amino acids 2011
case study : BTK kinase domain Mao et al . JBC 2002, Khan and Vihinen In silico biol 2009
PON-P (Pathogenic-Or-Not - Pipeline) - meta predictor for variations

Christian Schaefer. Technische Universitat Munchen (Germany) 
Can we predict structural change upon point mutation?
Checking the effect of a point of mutation for example S7M on local structure of the protein
Proteins chains collected from PDB, strctl. similarity measure used : RMSD
Machine learning - seq based features from PredictProtein (www.predictprotein.org/) used
dataset - what constitutes a structural change? structural neutral : RMSD < 0.2 A (13,646 mutants); structural non-neutral RMSD > 0.4 (12,056 mutants) -- 6,409 sequences
some success in learning local structural change ; no success yet in correlation that to change in stability or function. But some intrinsic relation pertaining to stability

Gilad Wainreb. Tel Aviv University (Israel) 
Protein stability: A single recorded mutation aids in predicting the effects 
of other mutations in the same amino acid site.
used Bellkor collaborative filtering model, it is previously applied to ecommerce applications
3 model used - baseline estimation model, the neighborhood model, the latent factor model
Pro-Maya algorithm, precision is very high compared to other tools, it is also performs well  in its sequence based prediction scheme
The tool is available at http://bental.tau.ac.il/ProMaya...

Piero Fariselli. University of Bologna  (Italy) 
Predicting cancer-associated germline variations in proteins.
Problem - given a residue mutation (variation) in a protein predict if the mutation can be disease associated or neutral

predictors - mutation type and local environment (physical - chemistry); evolutionary information (HMM, profiles); protein function (GO); systemic properties (interactions, regulation, time-dependence...)
protein function has some problems - over-fitting problem (cross-validation of scores is need);
SNPs & GO - the seq. profile and GO-based predictor
our lab has two predictors - PhD-SNP and SNPs&GO
From uniprot a first of 6478 germline variations associated and listed in OMIM
Using blast as predictor is very crude method
methods : neural networks and SVMs
GO terms enriched are related to Cancer
Problems and future: Reliability of the annotations; experimental validation on real cases; extension of different diseases; definition of a pipeline

Alain Laederach. University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill (USA) 
Effects of disease-associated SNPs on the structure of the transcriptome.
alain@unc.edu
Mutations in 5' UTR of HBB causes beta-thalassemia
disease associated SNPs in UTRs are from HGMD - Biobase
Looked genome wide structure stabilizing haplotype

Keynote: Burkhard Rost, Technische Universitat Munchen (Germany) 
Trivial step from predicting the effects of SNPs to medicine.
www.rostlab.org
Lingo: change of amino acid: ns (non-synonymous SNPs), they are central players of diseases
individual medicine : make it connects, genes, epigenetics
get diseases high -throughput manner: GWAS, many times (patients, drugs); env. factors (virus and bacteria)
many challenges: high volutes of data, communication, annotation; function is known for 10-50% human
prediction of nSNPs - some in silico methods SIFT, PolyPhen, SNPs3D
Misfunction/neutral - for machine learning method need lot of data, collected 80k mutations with known effects on functions  -- Y Bomberg and B Rost 2007 NAR 35: 3823-35
Y Bomberg and B Rost 2008 Bioinformatics 24: i207-212
New directions - in silico alanine scan; comprehensive in silico mutagenesis; prediction of binding hot spots
nsSNP effect: more detail - secondary structure (helix, strand) robust under random mutation , disorder not.  Molecular dynamics (MD) also playing a important role.
MD2: new SNPs  causing Parkinson's disease - A Zimprich et al. & T Meitinger & Tm Strom (201) - exome seq reveals mutations in the retromer protein vps35
Disordered regions - eukaryotes dominated disorder (4 - 10x)
prediction methods used MD, IUPred - eukaryota - 36 - 43%, where as bacteria 10 - 13%
Trivial step from prediction the effects of SNPs to individual medicine - connect many resources, and look at the details, so we have to work together.
Company Presentation: Frank Schacherer, BIOBASE GmbH.  SNP analysis with high quality data

only 56% of known disease mutations are Mis/Non-sense splice mutations  - 22% of min/nonsense mutations estimates to affect alt splicing and 10% of all diseases causing mutations are splice site mutations
Biobase contains manually curated data, the quality of data is very high
HGMD professional - completed inherited disease mutations ...
Nice paper listing different mutation databases  Baralle et al EMBO report VOL 10 No 8 2009
email : frank.schacherer@biobase-international.com
Booth #19

Highlight Speaker: Atul J. Butte, Stanford University (USA) 
Data-driven Personalized Medicine
addressing the medical use of personal genome
Ref genome contains with 2.8 million SNPs, 752 copy number variants
3 genes TMEM43, DSP, MYBPC3 associated with sudden cardia death  ... Ashley et al (2010), Lancet 375:1525
Current SNP-disease DBs are too limited for application to a human genome
Due to the current limitations with the existing dbs (mess of IDs), developed a new dbs from 5k manually curated papers
Curation challenges - most findings are in tables and figures making NLP hard
SNPs were reported as from Positive strand and negative strand
There is a quite difference between Odds ratio (OR) and Likelihood ratio (LR)
Fagen TJ. Nomogram for Bayes theorem N Rngl J Med 1975 Jul 31;293(5):257
Medical practitioners using LR since ages.
Pacific Biosystems: sequencing human genome in 15 minutes - 20TB in 15 minutes
During famine no body obese, so environment playing a import role along genome

Ontology-driven Indexing of Public Datasets for Translational Bioinformatics
N. H. Shah, C. Jonquet, A. P. Chiang, A. J. Butte, R. Chen, M. A. Musen
BMC Bioinformatics, Volume 10. Published in 2009
Family history (genomics) is also very import to understand the diseases
human toxome project
He recommend a book - experimental man by david ewing duncan

Konrad Karczewski. Stanford University (USA).  
Assessing Functional and Clinical Significance of Regulatory Variants.
SNPs in coding regions slightly high
In whole genome 7.5% SNPs found in TF binding sites, so SNPs can affect the TF binding site .....Karczewski et al 2011 PNAS in press
SNPs in NFkB regions are associated to more disease compared to others regions
Disease ~ SNP ~ Binding ~ Expression ~ Disease  .. gave example SNP associated to AIDS susceptibility  and Asthma

Joel Dudley. Stanford University (USA). 
Evolutionary meta-analysis reveals ancient constraints affecting missing 
heritability and reproducibility in disease association studies.
Varimed : manually curated database

Adam Frankish. Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute, Hinxton (UK) 
Is Understanding Alternative Splicing IPotential Functional Effects of SNPs?
GENCODE rich in Alt splicing
LoF project - Loss of function varients
Catalogue of LoF variation created from all three 1000 genome pilot projects
Manual annotation reveal .. ~36% (213/597) putative LoF variants present in AS exons
Artefacts - 44 putative genome seq errors. 243 errors in gene models (<5% pre-existing manually annotate models)
MS data, and published evidence can help to determine where the alt splicing is functional
GENCODE manual annotation provides a rich set of alt splice variants
Loss of function should be considered at the level of transcription, not at the locus level
www.gencodegenes.org version v8

Sudhir Kumar. Arizona State University, Tempe (USA). 
Comparative Genomics as an Evolutionary Telescope foMedicine to Peer into the Universe of Human Mutations.
Phylomedicine .... Kumar et al 2011 - Trends in Genetics coming in September issue
Genomic Medicine - Healthcare tailored to the individual based on genomic information - Green et al (2011) Nature
Interested in Protein alleles (nSNVs)
$100 exome may come soon
Number of alleles are increasing - Ng et al 2010 Human Mol Biol
Green et al 2011 Nature 470, 204 - 213 ... very nice paper related genomic medicine
At this moment Genome medicine lost in variation space, so the evolutionary history can help, at least provide first glimpse. Phylomedicine can help
Evol. telescope, two pieces of glass - Evol divergence and evol conservation
The evol rate is directly proportional to number of SNPs
Mol evolutionary and phylogenetic information is going to be crucial in improving diagnosis accuracy; Long term evolutionary properties can be estimated with high accuracy a priori

Keynote: Steven Brenner, University of California, Berkeley (USA). 
CAGI Experiments
CAGI- Critical Assessment of Genome Interpretation - www.genomeinterpretation.org
CAGI 2010 (http://cagi2010.org ) - 6 datasets, 108 prediction submissions etc
Personal genome project (PGP) - predict individual's phenotypes
riskSNPs: Mechanisms underlying Disease Associated Loci
WTCCC Loci, number of loci related to 7 diseases (Bipolar disorder, coronary artery disease, Crohn's disease, Rheumatoid arthritis, Type 1 and Type 2 diabetes)
CAGI 2011 - datasets - Breast cancer cell line pharmacogenomic dataset - 54 cell lines - 54 disease cell lines and several other data sets .... look at www.genomeinterpretation.org

body: Network Biology SIG: On the Analysis and Visualization of Networks in Biology

comments.body: Keynote 1: Gary Bader - Network and pathway information: collecting, visualizing and using for gene function prediction
Goal of computational cell map. Review of Systems Biology Pyramid (Cary et al 2005)
Collection of pathway resources continually growing (pathguide.org)
Increased activity in utilizing community standards. Data integration and sharing other key steps. Example of Pathway Commons (pathwaycommons.org)
cpath^2 - next generation demo - www.pathwaycommons.org/pc2-demo (emphasis primarily on web services)
Cytoscape 3 is under development. Complete re-architecture. OSGI - everything is a plug-in. Wide developer pre-release in fall.
web version of cytoscape - http://cytoscapeweb.cytoscape.org/ - ability to integrate into existing websites. Also moving to HTML5 (iPAD compatible)
genemania.org - tool for function prediction. Predicts additonal gene related to existing genes in network
Pathway representation trade-off: Coverage vs. depth
National resource for network biology - new funding initiative http://nrnb.org/
Q: Issue of consensus in community? A: group must have goal in mind that they want consensus. takes time but worth it and will result in standards people are happy with in community

Talk: Guanming Wu – “Reactome Functional Interaction (FI) Cytoscape
plugin: A network module-based tool for cancer data analysis”
Coverage problem major issue.  solutions: import pathways from pathway databases and  import pair-wise relationships

must address pair-wise problem (data model issue - to addresss can convert reactions in pathways into pair wise relationships "functional interactions" ; False positive - scoring system needed to score reliability for protein-protein interactions using Naive Bayes Classifier)
FI network : can signifcantly increase coverage
FI cytoscape plug-in.  Network clustering analysis included (Newman PNSA 2006); Cancer gene index annotation; Survival analysis
More details: http://wiki.reactome.org/index...
Application use case: breast cancer
Talk: Natasa Pržulj – “Integrative network alignment and analysis: MI- GRAAL and GraphCrunch”
GRAAL: a family of network alignment algorithms
For more info on GRAAL and MI-GRAAL: http://is.gd/ZGONIM
GraphCrunch 2: Software tool for network modeling, alignment and clustering http://is.gd/WvYBCF
TALK: Daniela Nitsch – “PINTA: A web server for network-based gene prioritization from expression data”

Keynote 2: Henning Hermjakob - "Reactome, IntAct, PSICQUIC:
Bringing pathways and interactions together"
PSI Comon Query Interface (PSICQUIC) - Nature methods 2011 (http://www.nature.com/nmeth...)
Need for overall scoring system . However underylying data fundamentally different. Created framework to make different scoring systems comparable
PSISCORE - registry model similar to PSICQUIC

Talk: Ian Donaldson – “iRefScape: A Cytoscape plugin for visualization and
data mining of protein interaction data from iRefIndex”
Key website: http://irefindex.uio.no/
IRefIndex -consolidation of approx 10 different databases - feedback to parent databases; lineage and provenance; meta-data regarding transformations
Go back to sequence data and can assign keys in order to verify that different accessions are indeed referring to the same entity. Exact sequence matches
n-ary data representations - different models: spoke, bipartite, etc. Has gone to lengths to keep this data distinct.

Panel: Daniela Nitsch, Esti Yeger Iotem, John Pinney, Jing Li : 
“Networks and Gene Lists”
John Pinney - Disease gene identification. Use seed gene approach. Specifically random walks with restarts (Kohler et al approach)
variation on approach- using different data types individually. Use of semantic similarity for annotations
Perform "data fusion" - average random walks across data types
Given some networks more informative and have seed genes - can use cross-validation to measure how much weight should be given to each source of evidence
Use pre-computed random walks. Web interface diana - disease association by network analysis
Jing Li - gene relationship measure via diffusion kernel calculation for each network. 3 diffusion kernel matrices are then normalized so they can be compared directly
compared with Endeavour (Aerts et al 2006, Tranchevent et al 2008) - mulitple sources, Kohler, plus traditonal network algorithms
Paper reference: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc...
Web tool: http://cbc.case.edu/dir
Esti Yeger Iotem - goal is to understand cellular response to stimulus (genetic screens and mRNA profiling)
ResponseNet - identify regulatory pathways leverging PPI data
If connected 2 genes lists via PPI = hairball. Used min-cost flow algorithm to maximize the connectivity while maintaining sparse solution
bioinfo.bgu.ac.il/respnet
need entry point into cell for any data type
Keynote 3: Trey Ideker: Asessing networks that are both structural and functional
understand how networks faciliate information flow in addition to how information is structured
"Active modules" (originally proposed in 2002) - co-cluster in unsupervised way to pull out enriched subnetworks
Example - HIV infection associated active modules (collaboration with Sumit Chanda)
supervised network biomarkers approach - Han-Yu Chuang 2007 - subnetworks with average expression predictive of progression
Network-guided decision tree induction (protein network biomarker application) - Dutkowksi et al Plos Comp Bio in press (network guided random forests)
cross-comparison of networks - conserved regions in +/- stimulus or across different species - network alignment + interaction scores= high scoring desnse conserved complexes

new data - atlas of combinatorial interactons among TF;human and mouse; TF-TF interactions; 1200 TF assays; 762 TF-TF interactions in human; 877 TF-TF in mouse; qRTPCR measurements of TF abundance across 34 adult tissues
Highly conserved networks between human and mouse - example: TF-TF in Brain
Compliment approach- specifically target differences in genetic networks across conditions
measuring genetic interactions with "product " model  - if deviation from expectation (product of two) can id significant postive or negative interactions
Challenge with DNA damage - does network remodel? 418 genes examined. 182 TF 111 Kinases 37 phosphatases 35 chromtin remodelers, as well as the known DNA damage genes
Untreated network; treated network and then 3rd network (ratio/subtraction) = differential
Noted that differential networks capture DNA damage response networks; Static networks do not.
Problem appears to be "housekeeping interactions"

Relationship between genetic and physical. Explored idea they are not overlapping but instead orthogonal. Gene A is part of Complex B mindset. Look for sets tightly connected with each other and then pairs aross sets.  Cytoscape plugin Srivas et al Nature protocols In Press
Network assembly via framework of filters (removing interactions) and integrators

Talk: Barbara Mirel – “Gaining knowledge and coherence
from complex networks and interactive activity trails”
Issues of usability and exploratory analysis -need for coherence and orientation
VisTrails - implementation for complex data not well structured  www.vistrails.org/
cognitive models for manageable load
Alfonso Valencia talks about cancer pathway analysis.
Ihop from Robert Hoffmann mentioned as a good source of network information. http://www.ihop-net.org/UniPub...
Andrei on collecting data about chromatin modification http://wodaklab.org/dancer/

body: HiTSEQ 2011 SIG: High Throughput Sequencing

comments.body: Kick off with Keynote 1 - Pamela Hoodless from Department of Medical Genetics, University of British Columbia. title -"From genomics to embryology "
Introduction to embryology and especially on liver development followed by need to generate new liver cells for transplantation.
Comparision of hepatoblast and hepatocyte transcriptomes -  14% genes differentially expressed.
FoxA2 and HNF4a comparisons
Bioinformatics challenge from a biologist point of view - Need effective data intergration tools
Talk: Ali Mortazavi	ChIP-seq regulatory analysis using ChIA-PET
Overview - abundance of directed graphs in biology
goal: chip-seq to regulatory networks. Can id 1000s of binding sites - which are functional? which genes do they regulate?
Simonis 2007 - can we connect distal chip-seq peaks to their target?

CHIA-PET (Nature 2009 - estrogen receptor). Ongoing collaboration with Yijun Ruan @ GIS. Same steps as ChIP-seq in beginning. Then add linkers, liagte them, cut enzymatically and map to look for overlaps.
CHIA-PET vs 5C vs Hi-C 5C - high resolution/local; HI-C - global but low resolution
ChIP-seq Regulatory Analysis using connections. Map ChIA-PET between peaks. Convert into graph
Graphs: datasets form local graph components  - no mega-components. Direct connections clear meaning. Indirect less clear.
TSS of highly expressed genes are more likely to be in the chromain interaction graphs
Many TSS show high connectivity. Restrict to edges only connected to other TSSS - 30.6% coonnected to 2 or more other TSS
Change in TSS degree correlates with change in expression
Example: TSS clique in myogenin locus. 12% of expressed genes in promoter cliques -> transcription factories (genes not transcribed singly but as group)
Myogenin cliques - idea of "TF depots"
19% of interactions to TSS are more than one TSS away
TSS form preferential attachment sites within their chormain interaction graphs (CIGS)
Q: exact or near cliques? A: exact Q:clarification of attachment sites preference A: based on inference from TSS connectivty patterns
Talk: Andrew Roth: JointSNVMix : A Probabilistic Model For Accurate Detection Of Somatic Mutations In Normal/Tumour Paired Sample Sequence Data
Software link: http://compbio.bccrc.ca/...
germline mutations are often mistaken for somatic due to under-sampling in normal data. algorithms that analyze data individually would be more susceptibe to this. Rationale for joint approach
joint genotype space (gn, gt)
Benchmark data set - Metrics: dbSNP concordance (surrogate for true germlines)- can explicitly ask if joint analysis reduces number of germline mutations mistakenly called as somatic
2nd metric: ROC - is there a gain / loss in performance using joint methods?
model admixture of normal/tumor in tumor sample needs to be addressed.
need to address temporal aspect - normal -> primary->metastasis

body: SIG: Bio-Ontologies

comments.body: Kicked off by Olga Tcheremenskaia on OpenTox Predictive Toxicology Framework: toxicological ontology and semantic media wiki-based OpenToxipedia (see: http://www.opentox.org/opentox...)
Keeping on a toxicology/pharmacological theme, Paea Le Pendu next up with "Annotation for Testing Drug Safety signals."
Enrichment analysis for off-label use of drugs, e.g. Avastin (normally cancer drug) – can see what other uses people use it for (Maxular degeneration, etc.).
No show for the 3rd talk (boo), so extended coffee break to let people put up posters.
After a refreshing break Chao Pang (EBI) has started the session talking about the Coriell Cell Line ontology: rapidly developing large ontologies.
>2000 cell lines. 93 organisms map OK to NCBI taxonomy ontology. 11 cell types and 61 anatomy types map OK to EFO ontology, but 337 disease types map a bit with OMIM but don’t have direct ontologies,
Is a large ontology (>28,000), but easy to add new classes/cell-types.
Now up is James Eales with a kidney disease data mining talk: An exercise in kidney factomics: from article titles to RDF knowledge base.
Why titles: succinct, easy to collect, hard to lie, your advert to the world.
Found ~86,000 titles for "renal" or "kidney".
Keynote talk now from Andre Su (Scripps) on cultivating and mining the gene wiki for crowdsourced gene annotation. One of the few wikis and crowdsourcing efforts that works.
Of genes in pubmed: 59% have <5 entries, 38% have none. Poorly annotated because sparsely curated.
Wikipedia best example of how to utilise "long tail" of internet users, and is generally quite accurate. Currently ~10,000 gene “stubs” within Wikipedia.

For something like Fibronectin – 28,000 articles in pubmed that can be integrated into 1 article. Community writing of review articles for every gene would be v powerful – great example is Reelin: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki....
To make it more reliable need to rank quality of edits/editors. Novartis wikipedia entry said "company name is derived from old Greek and means "destroyer of birds". [false]
Hairball backlash! Argument these are mostly decorative – AS made a better visualisation linking top 100% genes, most active editors and GO terms.
After lunch first talk from Mary Shinoyama (Rat Genome Database http://rgd.mcw.edu/) on “Using multiple ontologies to annotate and integrate phenotype records from multiple sources.”
Now up is Ben Good – linking genes to diseases with a SNPedia-Gene wiki mashup.
SNPedia http://www.snpedia.com/ has no info on gene function, so combine with Andrews Gene Wiki using mediawiki API.
SNPedia has “Medical Condition” category, but used NCBO annotator as more accepted link to disease ontologies. Enhanced disease pages in gene wiki with tables on related genes and SNPs.
Easy to integrate many of these types of applications as many share the same API
Code available at http://tinyurl.com/ismbmashup
Ravensara Travillian couldn't make it, but has a stand-in on "a vertebrate bridging ontology VBO". See: http://vbo.sourceforge.net/
Paolo Ciccarese next with DOMEO: a web based tool for semantic annotation of online documents. No more notes for now as battery about to die.
Susanna Asante overcome serious powerpoint conversion issues to present on the Biosharing network: http://www.biosharing.org/. Discussed it's evolution and relationship to ISA-tab and MIBBI
Trish Whezel next with an update on collaborative development of ontologies using webprotege and Bioportal.
Michael Schroeder talk from the morning session rescheduled, so now presenting: Maximum-Entropy for Annotation
See: http://www.gopubmed.com/
Works by MESH terms (4078 for disease, anatomy, etc). Ambiguity = more docs in pubmed and web.

After an interactive session around the ontology tools it’s now time for final flash updates. First up is Astrid Laegreid with Automated Assessment of High Throughput Hypotheses on Gene Regulatory Mechanisms Involved in the Gastrin Response.
Next is Fidel Ramirez on a new search method to mine biological data. Input gene/protein annotations.
Can discover new disease annotations by using functional similarity using OMIM data. See http://biomyn.de
Next is Warren Kibbe on: Coupling disease and disease genes using Disease Ontology (DO), NCBI GeneRIFs and the NCBO annotator service. See: http://doga.nubic.northwestern.edu
Up next is Anna Zhukova on KiSAO: Kinetic Simulation Algorithm Ontology. Follows MIASE guidelines.
Enables accurate & repeatable execution of computational simulation tasks. Page here: http://biomodels.net/kisao/
Now up is Jon Ison (EBI) on EDAM Ontology for bioinformatics tools and data. EDAM = Embrace Data and Methods Ontology (not classifying Dutch cheese).
See: http://sourceforge.net/project...
Rescheduled talk from Robert Yao on machine learning on a translational biomedical ontology for Alzheimer’s disease.

Internet problems this morning, but already had talks from Matthew Horridge on the state of biomedical ontologies (from a logic based perspective), Robert Stevens on Exploring Gene Ontology Annotations with OWL, and now up is Stefan Schulz on Records and Situations. Integrating contextual aspects in clinical ontologies.
First talk of the final afternoon was Nils Grewe with a talk on “Relating Processees and Events for Granularity-neutral modeling.
Janna Hastings next with a talk on "Processes and Properties". Used heart rate modeling as an example.
Further Flash updates from Janna Hastings (ChEBI) and Julius Jacobsen on an ontology integrating Uniprot-Macie+Catalytic Site Atlas. 5/6 Ontology updates were from the EBI.

Final invited data-mining talk from Andrew Chatr-Aryamontri and Martin Krallinger on detecting associations between scientific articles and ontology terms – the Molecular Interaction Ontology and BioCreative text mining challenges experience. Work on BioGrid database.
See: http://thebiogrid.org/. Lots of similar PPI databases – federated in IMEx consortium. Using compatible models allows sharing of curation load.

body: 3Dsig: Structural Bioinformatics & Computational Biophysics Satellite Meeting

comments.body: Yves Dehouch: Prediction of thermal vs. thermodynamic stability changes upon mutagenesis in proteins. Statistical potential for prediction of stability changes upon mutations in proteins. Potential contains terms based on amino acid distance distribution, solvent accessibility and so called coupling (residues have different configurations in protein surface vs. core)
Fast method, thousands of mutations evaluated in a second
Developing a temperature-independent version of the potential for more accurate/consistent thermal stability vs. melting temperature prediction

Anne Goupil: Computational scanning mutagenesis of proteins and protein interactions. Design studio 3.1 contains new protocols: Calculation of effect of mutation on binding affinity in protein complexes and effect of mutation on stability.

CHARMM based algorithm using modified CHARMM force field,
Generalized Born implicit solvent (also implicit membrane modeling possible)

Keynote 2: Rebecca Wade, Insights into molecular recognition from simulation of protein diffusion. Protein-protein docking: Complex structure prediction with SDA method using first rigid body docking with BD, then select representatives, and in the end flexible docking using MD. Experimental contraints used in the process.
Multiple protein simulations with SDAMM. Application on hydrophobin I. Found encounter complexes of tetramers that have same shape as crystalized tetramer, but not fully bound conformation.
Prosurf: computational toolbox for protein surface docking . BD, QM, MD and experiments combined.
Roland L. Dunbrack: Identifying biologically relevant interactions in protein crystals.

Biological unit vs. asymmetric unit problem. ProtCID procedure done on whole PDB. Sequences qrouped using PFAM. Chain architectures and pair architectures are compared. Interface comparisons inside each group. Clusterig of interfaces by hierarchical clustering.
Guido Capitani: Is it biologically relevant? An evolutionary method for distinguishing biological interfaces from crystal contacts.

Biologically relevant interfaces are the result of evolution, but crystal contacts are not. Hence, biological interfaces have a detectable signal. Core-Rim Ka/Ks ratio used as a measure of selection pressure.
Christine Orengo talks about enzyme evolution with specificity changes in their binding regions

Keynote 3: Christine Orengo,Sub-classifying relatives in CATH domain structure
superfamilies to explore protein function evolution
a lot of effects by a new interacting domain
Funtree developed by Janet Thornton
HUP CATH superfamily tree - 6 distinct structural clusters
CORA and FugueAli str and seq alignment methods
FLORA - identifies conserved and distinct structural elements
FLORA algorithm studies common/distinct features within a family
Changes in conserved residues in the active sites results in totally different enzymes
Optimization of FunFams with SFLD Structure-Function linkage database
FunFam - optimisation and validation using structure function linkage database (SFLD), homology models can be built using this data with low seq. id.
what does domain function mean? good point
Next release of CATH will contain also SNPs, conservation, functional site information
Nicholas Furnham: Investigating enzyme evolution in structurally defined superfamilies
half of all proteins are enzymes?
FunTree pipeline overview
FunTree pipeline - domain view and seq. view combined, phylogenetic tree generated and processed as well as annotated with additional data such as KEGG, catalytic site atlas etc.
Similarities based on small molecules (reactions to them or are they metabolites?)
Julian Gough, Virosphere-specific protein folds
the virosphere is too often overlooked
several viral specific domain families exist (63), found in all major functional classes of viruses and most fold classes

Noah Ollikainen: Structure based prediction of natural residue covariation using
computational protein design

Residue covariation is a general property in natural protein sequences, want to use this in computationally designed sequences. Backbone flexibility increases similarity between designed and natural covariation. Amino acid composition is similar in designed and natural sequences.
Andrew J. Bordner, Orientation-dependent backbone-only scoring functions for protein design
Keynote 4: Charlotte Deane, Modelling of Membrane Proteins
Medeller outperforms Modeller on membrane proteins. Using membrane protein specific substitution matrix in scoring.
Loop modelling  done with FREAD and using membrane protein specific database.
There are now enough data on membrane protein structures that can be used to parametrize MP specific tools

Alpan Raval, Homology model refinement via long all-atom molecular
dynamics simulations. They used all-atom CHARMM FF, well-sampled
100 microsecond simulations, explicit solvent model. Study shows that force field errors are still a limitation.

Alessandro Pandini: Detection of allosteric signal transmission by informationtheoretic
analysis of protein dynamics
MD simulation used to sample conformational space of a protein, small fragment conformations (structural aplhabet) observed at different time points, network of correlated fragment changes studied.
They found major similarities in dynamics of homologous domains

Keynote 6: Ruth Nussinov,Structural proteome scale prediction of protein-protein
interactions using interfaces.
A step towards adding time dimension in protein-protein interaction networks. Interaction interfaces predicted on monomers,which interactions can take place simultaneously are studied.

Hegyi Hedi, The relationship between proteome size, structural disorder and organism complexity. G-value paradox: complexity does not correlate with gene number. Resolved: one should consider I-value (information content). Protein families expanding in evolution are more disorderd.
Keynote 7: Torsten Schwede, Sins and Virtues in Protein Structure Homology Modelling

Thorsten Schwede's current challenges for Homology Modelling to make the models easily usable for end users: 1) absolute local error estimates; 2) models including cofactors and local detail; 3) oligormers

Keynote 7: Thorsten Schwede, Sins and Virtues in Protein Structure Homology
Modelling. Why to use automated homology modelling? Modeling experts do not scale very well, you can't fight the data deluge

body: Keynote: Olga Troyanskaya - Integrating computation and experiments for a molecular-level understanding of human disease

comments.body: Olga is not here but will have talk via video and then live Q&A remotely
Introduction by Alfonso Valencia. Olga Troyanskaya cannot be here because of a recent new family member. of hers. (# Congratulations)
Her lab takes large-scale molecular biology datasets and develops pathway level models
Tissue- and developmental-stage-specificity is important.
Example: DNA damage repair with many different types of interactions.

Pathway connections between proteins meaning correlated or connected function as opposed to protein-protein or regulatory interactions.  Connection means confidence that the two proteins are working together to accomplish some biological function.
Bayesian networks for data integration.
The graph is context-specific.
A case study of mitochondria: Yeasts unlike humans can live without mitochondria.
Do these networks discovery novel biology?  Case study of mitochondria.
Goal is to see if we can find proteins previously unknown to be involved in mitochondrial function, and test those predictions by knocking out the gene and looking at phenotype.
Two iterations results in finding all predictions that can be tested with single knock-out.
Went from 106 to 350 proteins known to be involved in mitochondrial biogenesis, in a few months.
109 of these predictions are completely novel; 135 more do have prior literature evidence but hadn't yet made it into Gene Ontology.
Instead of this computational candidate approach, they could have done genome-wide knock-out, and tested with that assay; it would have taken them 8 years, so this is a huge time savings (and cost!)
More than 50% of the genes have an ortholog in human.

The newly annotated genes that they find tend to show a quantitative phenotype as opposed to being necessary for any respiration.  These are more likely to be relevant to human disease, I think because the ones that are strictly necessary would be lethal mutations...
Computational predictions from large collection of genomic data can be accurate despite incomplete or misleading old standards.
So that was yeast, but you can also take an approach of looking directly at human data.
Their system allows you to ask what diseases a particular gene is involved in.
They use 650 datasets that include 30,000 conditions.  I assume this is mainly gene expression profiling data.
These predictions can be tested.  Hilary Kohler (sp?) at Princeton has tested 7 of the predictions; 6/7 confirmed.
Tissue specific gene expression -- in worm, this has been carefully elucidated; see WormBase.
With Coleen Murphy at Princeton - taking out whole worm expression and figure out tissue-specific expression from it.  ?
They do genetic perturbation of genes in the untranslated response pathway and make some interesting findings that were not previously known.

I am confused about the finding that they can predict tissue specificity even if they take that tissue out of the compendium.  Did I get that right?  How can you predict the tissue if you have zero examples of it?
# Not sure what the UTR pathway was here either.
Now moving on to a human example:  kidney disease
Damage to glomerular filter causes disease.

There is no way to microdissect podocytes; at most can dissect glomerular filters.  A collaboratler at MI, Kretzler, has some gene expression profiles of this tissue.  They're going to try and predict podocyte expression.
They take the expression compendium and positive and negative examples of mixed samples (various cell lineages) that include podocytes, I think.
They can refer to other datasets like mouse, in situ staining, and so on.
They want podocyte-specific genes that are enriched for clinically relevant genes.
DACH1 expressed in the human kidney, also expressed in the homologous organ in fish.
She now talks about follow-up work, unpublished, on some specific genes.

One way to assess the predictions is to look at the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) which reflects kidney function; the expression of the predicted genes does relate to GFR.  So the predictions are clinically relevant.
HOW are these proteins involved in the process?  What are these genes doing in the podocytes or in the kidney?  (she asks)
She looks at the genes in a network built based on what we already know about gene and protein relationships.
She shows the brain network and genes known to be involved in Alzheimer's disease.
Moving on to the topic of finding genotype-disease associations with functional genomics.  This is like GWAS done with genetic data, but here wtih functional genomics.

Input:  tissue-specific functional relationship networks.  + genes involved in specific phenotypes (from mouse data, Jackson Labs).  Then an SVM classifier tries to find new genes with evidence of connection to different phenotypes.
This works.  And it definitely helps to be considering tissue specificity instead of just using global networks.
Let's look at a specific prediction:  bone mineral density.
There are 20 GWAS loci but these only explain 3% of heritability.  !
Two genes: Timp2 and Abcg8 are in the top 100 predictions; they don't overlap with other previous studies, and there is a KO model in mouse.
So they looked at the bone density phenotype in these knockout (KO) mice.
Male mice do have signficiant reduction in BMD.  (One graph looks like increase - what am I missing?)

With Hess & Huttenhower, infer physical, genetic, regulatory and functional networks, from the functional genomics data.  Specific interaction types (like phosphorylation) are hard to predict because of the small amount of gold standard data.
They have an ontology of interaction types; this hierarchical relation can improve their systems.
I've lost track of what the input data is here; the output predictions are specific types of relationships between pairs of proteins.
Example of JAG1, looking for its targets; it is known to be a mediator of bone metastasis in breast cancer.  They made a prediction of one target that they hope to confirm.

Another example in the NOD-like receptor signaling pathway.  They held out some data and showed that they could regenerate it.  They also had a novel prediction of an inhibitory relationship, which is consistent with some indirect experimental evidence in the literature, and relevant to a disease.

Summary:  computational analyses of diverse large datasets, especially using tissue-specific information and modeling, can help pinpoint disease genes and processes that have been missed by other techniques like GWAS.

We need to link the micro-level biochemical events with physiological-level events like blood pressure.  We also want to do this in the context of individual genomes - personalized medicine - to guide appropriate treatment for each patient.

Acknolwedgements:  Huttenhower (now at Harvard).   Chad Myers, David Hess, Matthew Hibbs.  Maria Chikina - worm.  Casey Greene - podocytes.  Yuanfang Guan - collaborating with Jackson Labs.  Chris Park -- pathways work.  Many more.
function.princeton.edu; open source library C++, highly optimized, developing with Huttenhower, useful for repeating the analyses or applying tools to other datasets.
Q: Are the edges in tissue specific networks? A: Both edges and nodes are tissue specific.

body: LBR08: Wei-Jen Chung - Post-transcriptional regulators of microRNA biogenesis regulate pathogenesis of cancer

comments.body: Introduction on microRNA biogenesis
Other kind of microRNA: mirtron.
Obernosterer (2006): mir-138 is restricted to certain cell types, while the precursor is ubiquitously expressed.
Another interesting case: mature let-7 appers only in late stege of mouse development.
There are biogenesis regulators, such as HNRNPA1, P72 and P68.
LIN28, on the other hand, is a repressor of the let-7 family maturation.
Drosha itself can sometimes act as a repressor.
The aberrant expression of miRNA biogenesis regulators propagate across miRNAs.
Aim of the work: to identify disease-related post-transcriptional regulators of miRNAs.
Conditional mutual information was used to identify regulation.
Prediction results were validated using RT-PCR.
In the case of intragenic miRNAs, their expression profile should be correlated to that of the host gene.
But when there is a strong correlation with a third gene, that could be a regulator.
Polycistronic miRNAs can be used similarly. They should behave similarly: if they don't, there could be a regulator.
Example. SLIT3 (host) and mir-128 (mirna). They are correlated in expression depending on the presence of DDX10.
They predicted hundreds of such triplets both in ovarian cancer and in glioblastoma.
CNV variation data. Is there any variation in the predicted biogenesis regulators?
They found significant deletions or amplifications.
Silencing of DDX10 results in the repression of the maturation of miRNAs.
Another example. ACSM3: not a binding protein, but it significantly increases miRNA expression.

body: HL08: Andrew Bordner - Universal epitope prediction for class II MHC

comments.body: Introduction to Class II MHC. Binds 15-25 residue long peptides, more conserved backbone. Possibly easier to predict.
Highly polymorphic, each has different peptide preferences, 4 genes, alpha and beta (MHCII)
Epitope prediction: Two general types, patter finding in sequence and structure modeling based.
Pattern based methods fast, requires only known binding peptides. Cannot be generalized to dissimilar types.
Regularized Thermodynamic Average sequence-based prediction.

body: HL04: Benoit Ballester - Five-Vertebrate ChIP-seq Reveals the Evolutionary Dynamics of Transcription Factor Binding

comments.body: Reference: http://www.sciencemag.org/content...
Review of recent work on evidence that TF binding diverges very rapidly
Liver tissue in  human, mouse, dog, opossum and chicken. CEBPA chip; Illumina sequencing; MAQ and SWEMBL; 12-way amniota vertebrate alignment (Ensembl)
Examined pair-wise TFBS conservation; Number of conserved shared events decreases as move to more distant species
Across all 5-species - conservation of individual binding events is extremely rare
Sensitivity analysis to examine stringent vs lenient parameterization - no impact
CEBPA - extract in vivo motif in humans - motif is highly conserved across species
Examined TFBS loss, as well as turn-over events
trans chromic - TFBS affected by environment - can recapitulate all of Hs TF binding events with Mm TF on HS Chromosome.
Repeated with another TF - HNF4A
Follow-up work Zoo-ChIP 21-36% of human TF binding events can be found in macaque
21-40% of mouse TF binding events found in rat

body: TT04: Michael Reich - GenomeSpace

comments.body: Integrative genomics: multitude of data formats, tools and repositories.
Need to support wide variatey of integrative genomic analyses.
Need of communication between tools and repositories of data.
GenomeSpace an online community to integrate computational tools.
6 tools as initial seed.
Aimed towards non-programming users.
Tools: Cytoscape, Galaxy, GenePatern, Genomica, IGV and UCSC Genome Browser.
GenomeSpace right now is in beta.
Usage example: Studying the regolatory control of human hematopoiesis (based on Regev study).
The user interface abstracts over the actual location of data: can be local or in the cloud.
GenomeSpace automatically transfers and convert of data files between different tools.
All the tools maintain their original interface.
GenomeSpace architecture.
Single signon service.
Data manager to exchange data between the tools.
And API to extend existing applications (Java-based).
Also a REST API for web tools.
Now available a CDK (Client Development Kit) for tool developers.
Ope source code available in BitBucket.
Services now hosted on Amazon.
In Fall 2011: beta program for developers.
gs-tool-join@broadinstitute.org (for developers)
genomespace-users-join@broadinstitute.org (for users)
http://www.genomespace.org

body: TT03: Rachel Harte - UCSC Genome Browser:  Visualization tools for high-throughput sequencing

comments.body: http://genome.ucsc.edu
To add your own data, "Add custom tracks" button.

BED data displays as blocks (can be exons connected by introns).  Wiggle data allows graphical display of different values at each basepair.  bedGraph data allows 2D graphical display again with a different value possible for each bp, but specified more as blocks of basepairs with a given value.

With very large datasets, there can be problems uploading.  The solution is a binary indexed format; the file lives on your server, but it is indexed so that only the information for the region being viewed is uploaded.  This eliminates the need to upload very large files.
Next-gen sequencing data: again millions of short reads means files that are way too big to upload.

The solution is to align the reads using an aligner like SAMtools.  Then index these to create a .bai file (again can be done with SAMtools).  You make this indexed file avaialble to the browser via http or ftp.
http://samtools.sourceforge.net
To see a BAM file in action, use this session -  user: Example   session:hg18_bamSnps

Custom tracks are great for small datasets and a few datatypes.  These are persistent for 48 hours, then discarded.  You can extend their lifetime with the session feature.  You can share this privately with colleagues.
You create a wiki login (see instructions on the Session page) in order to do this.
The data is also available in the Table Browser

In development: data hubs. Prototype at http://genome-preview.cse.ucsc.edu. Good solution for large datasets where you want persistence and additional track functionality. The data files remain on a remote server accessible via http or ftp. Data formatted in one of the binary index formats.
The data hubs currently include a couple releases from the Epigenomics Roadmap.
You can configure the tracks to view or hide specific subtracks.
You can install a copy of the browser locally; this is free to academics and there is a commercial license for companies.

body: HL02: Jacques Colinge - The Central Human Proteome

comments.body: http://www.biomedcentral.com/1752-05...
Which are the commonly expressed in human?
7 cell lines, 1D gels, 50 bands, Orbitrap MS-MS
Membrane proteins underrepresented, no other biases for characteristics such as PI, MW found. Abundant proteins.
Overlap of 45% with Su, PNAS 2002 transcriptome study. Similar processes enriched.
Human protein atlas (Ponten, MSB, 2009), overlap of 40%, mass sensitivity limited.
Protein found generally well conserved. More interesting, genes are exon-rich.
Increased number of interactions.
The central proteome is central in the interactome (by centrality measures).
83% enzymes, 77% primary metabolism, significant enrichment in drug targets (176 from DrugBank)
Specialized functions of the core proteome interwoven by connectors.
10% of the core proteome are poorly annotated.
Significant overlap with viral host factors.
Data publicly available.
Q: Map of the central proteome against housekeeping genes?
A: No, not directly but other works defined abundant genes as such.
Q: Kinases as cancer targets, relevance in the data set? A: 40 kinases in the data set. Overlap with cancer much bigger than only kinases.
Q: Both expression levels and abundance levels. Correlation? A; Poor overlap between the two suggests expression levels are little correlated. [..]

Q: Have you looked at recent sequencing studies for transcriptomics [not only Su et al] . A: Studies by Chris Burge report 10.000 genes, much too many to compare because copy number might be very low, comparison very difficult. Unclear functional relevance.
Q: Centrality. Have you looked at the complexome? A: You recognize proteasome, spiicesosome. Q: How many is in complexes: A: Two thirds, there are not many complexes that work alone.
Q: Are poorly annotated proteins underrepresented? A: Depends on the number of PubMed abstracts that make a protein underrepresented.

body: LBR01: Milana Frenkel-Morgenstern - Potential function of proteins encoded by chimeric transcripts

comments.body: seminal paper: gingeras 2009 "Implications of chimaeric non-co-linear transcripts"
Li et al (2008) thousands of chimerica transcripts in budding yeast, fruit flt, mouse and human
In Drosophila, trans-splicing combines sense and anti-sense regions.
Kanna et al (2001): 2369 chimeric RNA in prostate cancer (via RNAseq)
32 highly abundant chimeric RNAS in prostate cancer cell lines
In human, proteins produced i "trans" with exons from different chromosomes
Example: Acyl-Coa (ACAT) from chr 1 and 7
Fusion protein in Chronic Myelogeneous Leukemia: the Bcr-Abl protein kinase
Why the high discrepancy between the number of chimeric RNAs and chimeric proteins?
chimaric RNAs could be artifacts
or functional at the RNA level only
Procedure to validate chimeric RNAs from various datasets
mapping of RNAseq reads
~8500 chimeric reads identified in human
chimeric ESTs were used as a template. Reads were mapped over them
Three datasets in human: ChimerDB (ESTs and mRNAs) and Li et al.
~170 chimeric RNAs validated with more than two reads.
abundance measured using Reads Per Kb mapped per Million reads (RPKM)
Chimeras were confirmed searching for peptides in junctions using mass-spec
Frenkel-Morgenstern, 2011 (submitted)
Example: chimera of RPL13A and ACGTG1
Confirmed by two overlapping peptides at the junction and by eight RNAseq reads in two tissues.
In human, 480 chimeric RNAs and 11 chimeric proteins confirmed.
Trans-membrane domains are frequenly found in chimeras (~50% in human).
Chimeras may produce a dominant negative effect => a mutation that affects the function of the normal gene.
In human, 14% of chimeras have potential dominant negative effect.
Chimera database: chimera.bioinfo.cnio.es

body: Keynote: Bonnie  Berger - Computational biology in the 21st century: making sense out of massive data

comments.body: ISMB/ECCB 2011 kicked off, Michal Linial is introducing the first keynote speaker
algorithmic challenges to increasingly massive amounts of data - how to avoid situation becoming intractable?
Berger showing a graph where data are growing faster than computational powere can handle (MIPS vs. bases / day)
10 fold increase in sequencing vs doubling in computing capacity
Not just a bigger cloud -- > need better algorithms
3 challenges areas - compression, signal from noise, patterns across species
Need to exploit fact that "new" data is similar - utilize redundancy "compressive genomics"
Work directly on compressed data rather than compress --> decompress
use case from fly genomes
Compression accelerated blast caBLAST
Redundancy in genomics can be exploited --> CaBLAST. Works on compressed data. Size of compressed DB is proportional to the size of non-redundant data
coarse analysis on compressed data - refined analysis on relevant regions
Run time much faster
never have to uncompress - potential for huge gains
use case 2: signal from noice (medical genomics)
Can't find cablast online...
Berger moving to NCBI GEO and medical trasncriptomics
Indexing GEO using UMLS -- Unified Medical Language System from NCBI
UMLS is an ontology of medical concepts.http://www.nlm.nih.gov/researc...
Concept enrichment in umls tool: concordia
Using UML and Concordia to analyze tumor origin
Thanks for the coverage!
Lab has several interesting tools like IsoRank, IsoRankN, Struct2Net, RNAicut, Mangoose and more
(network connection is bit bad)

body: SS01: Biolink

comments.body: SS01 - Part A: BioLINK: Integrating phenotypic data from electronic patient records with molecular level systems biology, Søren Brunak
text mining - ability to examine patient-ICD10 associations
Heatmap visualization to identify ICD10 co-occurrences
Can then overlay related genes in PPI networks - look for overlap between co-occuring clusters
Notes that while this work was done in Danish healthcare system - can easily translate across to other countries given indexing by ICD10
Qs related to heterogeneity; concern if ICD10 is appropriate phenotypic surrogate; how family information is handled (was removed in this study)
SS01 - Part B: BioLINK: Issues in Annotating Whole-Genome Data with Clinically Relevant Pharmacogenomics Knowledge, Russ Altman
Focus on PharmGKB (www.pharmgkb.org); annoation of sequence for anticipated drug response; challenge for rare variants
Patient Zero use case - 40 yr old male; no medications; existing disease-related family history
Entire genome sequence - Clincial assessment performed - one component was PharmGKB annotation
Article : http://www.thelancet.com/journal...
able to detect possible drug interaction. However, at time genome sequencing cost 40K. Q: was this worth it?
Abie to summarize potential complicatons in treatment which could fuel decision aids - as price point for sequencing drops increases value of information and feasibility of use
Also able to predict drugs with reduced adverse events, increased probability of effective usage
most interesting: novel SNPs in VIP genes (known to be important for drugs) that appear to be deleterious
Allows annotation of "unexpected response" to drug in clinical setting. Could allow you to use another class of drugs to avoid complications
Evaluating warfarin dosage with rare variants - Reference: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc...
IWPC GWAS in progress (N=342 African americans)
Quantitative scoring of minor allele burden - can correlate with dosage
SS01 - Part C: BioLINK: Instrumenting the Healthcare System to Define the True Names of Disease, Yves Moreau
Discussing issue of candidate gene prioritization - how best to systematically integrate information to allow better assessment and interpretation with regard to clinical setting
"Data fusion" problem - uses blind scientist and elephant analogy
One approach- prioritization by text mining (evidence-based)
Cartagenia Bench software: http://www.cartagenia.com/softwar...
outside of diagnostic setting - hypotheses for research : kernel methods for genomic data fusion
known/training genes and candiate test genes (Type 2 diabetes use case) - has very strong assumption that there will be common properties between genes

must recognize that text is retrospective source of information - when combine all data sources - dififcult to have unbiased benchmark - need to make sure it does not dominate as need for new discovery
Do you have a link to 'BioLink' ?

comments.body: Part A. Steven Brenner: Questions can be send online via E-mail, Twitter, etc. (@CAGInews)
http://genomeinterpretation.org/
Critical assessment of genome interpretation (CGAI): Blind assessment of phenotypes in the sense of CASP. Determine state of art, identify progress, bottlenecks, focus of efforts, innovation.
CAGI 2010 overview: http://www.nature.com/news...
Also, propose new problems and bring the community together. Not a competition but a learning exercise.
Susanna Repo: Introduction to CAGI2010.
CAGI2011: 9 datasets available, 3 more pending. Submission closes in fall.
Link for challenge datasets: http://genomeinterpretation.org/content...
Personal Genome variants, Risk SNPs, [....], .exome sequencing comparison of patients and healthy individuals.
Q: p53 double mutant dataset similar to last year. A: Yes, several issues with the data set(?)
Pauline Ng: Results fromm 2010: Successes and challenges.
SiFT algorithm
Dataset 1. Mutations in Cystathinione-beta-synthetase, causing Homocystinuria.
52 substitutions assay, comparison of high pyridoxine and low pyridoxine conditions.
23 conditions, comparison of AUC, Accuracy, spearman, z-score, RMSD.
Successful algorithms performed well in all metrics.
The best two algorithms used structure, sequence and annotation. Third sequence alone, fourth structure alone.
Cavets: only one protein, cannot be extrapolated, most algorithms used structure, but not known for other data.
Some good predictions made but some are wrong by most algorithms.
Methods are missing activating mutations  (2 examples shown) - key area for field
General problem with activating mutations. Problematic for drug targets in cancer.
Dataset 2: CHEK mutations. Increasing the risk of breast cancer. Sequenced in 1482 breast cancers and 1089 healthy controls.
32 AA mutations, 2 double substitutions. 3 pre-termination, 4 frameshifts.
Predicting phenotype - Karchin Lab video- BN20 approach - focused on significant variants (from association studies) and affected genes
Sequential bayesian with priors and BN20 approach - for each of 10 individuals
wiki.chasmsoftware.org
SNPedia - wiki like website for SNP annotation used in assessment
Panel discussion:

Russ Altman: prediction: in 10 years, prediction of phenotype of SNIP wi'll be about learning from known cases (parallel: for protein structure prediction, homology modelling is becoming more important), i.e. variants that are rare now will be seen more often due to increased coverage

body: Keynote: Alfonso Valencia - Challenges for Bioinformatics in Personalized Cancer Medicine

comments.body: Several questions: what proteins in a cell? How do the complexes form? Evolution of gene duplications/epigenetics? Personalising treatment will be final part of talk.
Mentions APPRIS webserver http://appris.bioinfo.cnio.es/proteo... (seems to down at moment)
OK, this is the current link http://appris.bioinfo.cnio.es/

Cool -- protein-protein docking programs can often identify correct binders from all the incorrect binders, even if the absolute score or estimate of binding energy is not correct, the relative estimates work to find correct binders among the top predicted binders.
Moreover, correct binders often have many conformations near the correct conformation that have good scores, which helps in the comparison to other (wrong) binding pairs.

(Question I have about looking for evidence at the protein level of the many observed mRNA splice isoforms:  can they see peptides that span exon boundaries?  wouldn't that provide very good evidence, but of course much rarer, compared to peptides that reside entirely within an exon?)
Docking data recently published in MSB http://www.nature.com/msb...

Chromatin structure plays a role in eukaryotic genomic evolution, as do DNA replication dynamics.  The act of replication induces cellular stress, with exposed single-strand DNA leading to DNA damage.
Ernst & Kellis:  we now have new genome-wide data showing chromatin states -- and can know which regions are euchromatic.
We also have maps of speed of replication along the human genome, showing late and early replication locations.
They use phylostratification for evolutionary trees of each human gene, back to when there was a duplication.

We now put together gene age, replication time and euchromatin.  We get a surprising result.  Old families replicate earlier; newer genes replicate later and are more exposed to replicative stress (and therefore are more vulnerable to change?)
Genes that replicate late in the cell cycle are in heterochromatin-rich regions.
Development of specialized cell types is one consequence of this process.
Moving now to Bioinformatics in personalized cancer treatment
Recommends Altman's review in Bioinformatics on bioinformatics in personalized medicine. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed...
Paper on PALB2, pancreatic cancer susceptibility gene found by exomic sequencing, resulting in better, rationally targeted cancer treatment for a patient.
International Cancer Consortium: Spain will sequence 500 genomes of Leukemia patients
Initlal paper - whole genome sequencing from 4 cases: http://www.nature.com/nature...
call for collaboration - interchanging of methods and validated data sets

body: HL23: Jean Peccoud - Strengths and limitations of the federal guidance on synthetic DNA

comments.body: References the 1918 spanish flu pandemic virus paper, Science 2005 310:5745.  Tumpey et al.  This was controversial because they actually resurrected a dangerous virus.
Biological warfare is as old as warfare itself.

The American anthrax ("Amerithrax") incident - 5 people died, and 17 people were infected.  But the decontamination and cleanup costs were probably greater than $1 billion.  This included cleanup of two postal facilities that were closed for years.  And the political cost:  NIH funding for biodefense was increased by $1.5B; in 2004, the Project BIoshield Act provided $5.6B.

There is an industry of gene synthesis companies.  You go to a web site, type in the sequence you want, and a few days or weeks later you get a small vial of your DNA.  In 2006, a Guardian erporter bought part of the smallpox genome for a few thousand dollars.  (James Randerson)

In 2009 the industry put together a couple of trade groups created to catalyze the industry response to concerns about the technology.  IGSC (International Gene Synthesis Consortium), 5 companies representing 80% of worldwide synthesis capacity - the "Harmonized somethin gor other..."
Fall of 2009, DHHS (USA Dept of Health and Human Services) published guidance for synthetic dsDNA -- not regulation.
One section is screening the customers (avoid those paying with cash...).  Another section is on sequence screening, there is also record retention and a government contact in the FBI.

So the speaker's group took on the guidance - they interpreted the draft guidance as an algorithm, and implemented it as software called GenoGUARD.  Then they tried to assess whether it was doing what it was supposed to do.  Which was to minimize the risk that unauthorized individuals will obtain agents of concern through the use of nucleic acid synthesis technologies - while minimizing negative impacts on research and business.

What are sequences of concern?  dsDNA sequences derived from or encoding select agents and toxins -- there is an agent registry.  Things like toxic bacteria.  Already there is a problem here -- this is a list of species, not DNA sequences.  Getting to the list of sequences is not completely trivial; there is no subset of Genbank labeled "select agents".
The sequences were those unique to select agents - not house-keeping genes.
You need to screen not only for DNA sequence but go the reverse direction from the protein encoded by the DNA sequence.
Needed to go down to 200 bps or more.
They recommended the best Match comparison.

Best match method:  when you run against BLAST, you look at % identity and query coverage.  You want 100% query coverage.  You can get multiple best matches - have to decide what to do if one is a select agent and the other is not.
They first tried running BLAST on NCBI - but this can only be done sequentially, and there is a lack of privacy.
So they do a local BLAST, which is computationally expensive.
Students in the iGEM workshop focused on this problem and ended up presenting to government agencies.
Consider the scenario that people in local hospitals start showing up with flu-like symptoms, and the problem is eventually traced to your lab.  How can you avoid this?
Consider offering your services to work on this important problem.
The "bad guys" are not usually off in a cave or working in a garage - in the case of Amerithrax, the origin was in a Navy lab.

body: HL20: Philip Kim - Bringing order to protein disorder through comparative genomics and genetic interactions

comments.body: Bellay et al., collaboration with Chad Myers and Gary Bader. http://genomebiology.com/2011...
Many proteins contain disorder regions which are difficult to study and tend to neglected. With a focus on domains but interdomain regions contains many relevant motives for binding.
General systematic survey of disordered interactions. Disorder is correlated with genetic interaction degree, holds for other data set, known for years.
gene interaction network as way to define functional disorder
Paradox: disordered proteins evolve fast, disordered hubs are conserved at the gene level.
Many disordered regions are conserved but not their content.
detect level of conservation in regions characterized by high level of disorder
use of disorder conservation score and sequence conservaton score - allow elucidation of 3 classes of disorder
3 classes: constrained disorder (residue); flexible disorder (residue); non-conserved disorder (residue)
different functions with each of these classes
Constrained disordered in chaperone Hsp90 forms a loop on the surface. Might work on the refolding of other proteins.
cancer driver mutations are enriched in constrained disorder
Q: Does your work suggest that with usual tours we are not able to conservation of disordered regions? A: Yes. There are different properties of disorder. We look at more data types.

Q: Hubs vs non-hubs? Previous speakers showed a correlation with multiple functions. Is there a  correlation? A: It's basically the same thing. Q: The floppy disorder regions allows it to do more things? A: Hmm, if you have more disordered regions have more opportunity
Q: Strong signal in the location of the protein, context important. A: Not explicitly looked at.
Q: Definition of disorder: Is there a number of AAs to define disorder? A: Might be a technical issue. We use Disorderpred2. Some artifacts from sliding window approaches, needs a minimal window.

body: HL16: Insuk Lee - Predicting genetic modifier loci using functional gene networks

comments.body: Changed title to "Finding missing inheritability using functional gene networks"
This is based on Lee et al, "Predicting genetic modifier loci..." and Lee et al "Prioritizing candidate disease genes by network-based boosting..."
GWAS is currently the most powerful approach for studying complex traits.  862 GWAS papers have been published, reporting more than 4306 trait-associated SNPs.
How much trait can we explain by these SNPs?  Nature Feb 2011 paper:  ranging from 12 to 60% of heritability of traits.
Two reasons for missing inheritability:  (1) epistasis (non-additive genetic effects), and (2) low statistical power to detect weak genetic penetration per each SNP.
Gene-trait mapping using gene networks to explain more.
Another approach:  gene-trait association mapping.  Construct functional gene networks using a Bayesian framework - Fraser & Marcotte, Nat Gen 2004; Lee et al Science 2004.
Combine different types of relationships to get better networks.
They look to see whether genes of interest are highly connected within the network.  If so, then the network is a good model for the genes, or for the phenotype that the genes are involved in.
They tested by looking at 100 knock-out (KO) phenotypes from the literature - McGary et al Genome Biology 2007
So this is yeast - how does this work in animal and plant, with many different tissue and cell types?
WormNet: works pretty well even if you ignore tissue type.  Also AraNet, HumanNet (Genome Biology 2011).
Back to missing inheritability.
They predicted about 174 new Rb suppressors using 5 known ones as seeds. Then they tested loss-of-function phenotype using RNAi, and validated 16 new suppressors.  This is in worm.
Hypothesis is that known disease gene modifiers that are well connected are likely to point to other modifiers for the same disease gene.  Lee, Lehner et al Genome Research 2010.
They tested the top 3 genes with high connectivity in worm.  They see a 7-fold enrichment compared to the original semi-random screen.
On to the second problem:  low statistical power.  With multiple testing, you need lots of data.  Many of the minor contributors are below the significance threshold.
Can a network help?
Lee, Blom, et al Genome Research 2011.

If the genes that are close to significant belong to the same pathways, we will rescue them.  We want them to be in the same pathways as the definitely-significant genes.  Use HumanNet (www.functionalnet.org/humannet) to look for "soft" guilt-by-association.

They looked at the Wellcome Trust Case Control Consortium.  They validated boosted genes by comparing to genes that were later validated with a larger sample size.  Examples include STAT3 and JAK2 in Crohn's disease, and GRB2 and SHC1 in gastric ulcer healing.
I don't have a clear understanding about how boosting compares to just relaxing the P-value threshold in the first place -- does he explain that?  I guess he must.
Another example in type 2 diabetes...

A trait is a complex system composed of many genes.  to model the system, first collect massive amounts of heterogeneous biological data, and create a "social network" of genes.  From here, we get networks and can carry out the analyses described above.
I wonder if they are cataloguing the results of their analyses across many diseases with known disease genes.

body: LBR11: Ana Conesa - Differential expression with RNA-seq: a matter of Depth

comments.body: While there are various applications of RNA-seq (fusion transcripts, extragenic expression, alt 5' and 3'; alt splicing; antisense expression), her group focuses on differential expression and especially the dynamic range of gene expression.
NOISeq is an approach they developed for analyzing RNA-seq data.
Advantages of RNA-seq over microarrays include no need of reference genome, strand specificity, finding novel splice sites, larger dynamic range, detection of rare transcripts.
There are some issues that you have to take into account.
Correlation between RNA-seq and microarray is reasonably high especially for highly expressed genes.  RNA-seq better at identifying differentially expressed genes.

RNA-seq biases:  There is correlation between expression level and transcript length, even with a normalization method like RPKM.  It is not always true that different samples have equal transcript distributions.  Or, hm, not sure I got that.
More on biases in RNA-seq data:  Differential expression depends on transcript length

Sequencing depth: the deeper you sequence, the better estimate of expression and the more rare genes you can detect.  To study this, used 3 public domain datasets, all in human.  kidney vs liver, 22M reads.  MAQC: brain vs UHR, 45M reads.  Griffith:  2 cancer lines, 200M reads.
Do not seem to reach saturation even with large datasets.  Continue to detect rare new genes.
If focus on the protein coding genes, we do seem to saturate at a certain number of reads.
Key point:  differential expression comparing samples should have similar library sizes.
Sequencing depth also affects the length of detected transcripts.

Compared to other methods that have parametric assumptions, need replicates and are unstable with low expressed genes.  They propose new methodology NOISeq, no need of replicates; non-parametric.  The look at log change value M and the absolute difference in the number of counts between two samples.
NOISeq-real uses available replicates; can simulate replicates when not available.
Their method has the same number of predicted differentially expressed genes as a function of depth of reads.  It has nice behavior across a number of different measures.

For some of the experiments, there is additional real-time PCR data.  Using this, could contrast whether some genes were actually differentially expressed or not.  The basic result was that with parametric approaches, false positives increased quickly with additional lanes of sequencing output.  Although these methods are available to identify a large number of deg's, many of them are false positives.  When it comes to false negatives, NOISeq is slightly worse than the parametric approaches.
Looked at differential expression in terms of GO terms.  Ah - deg's detected by other methods and not NOISeq are poorly annotated - suggests these might be false positives?

body: TT17: Paul Fisher - Software for the data-driven researcher: Annotation of Next Generation Sequencing SNP Data using scientific workflows

comments.body: The analysis problem: 22 million SNPs for 3 African cattle breeds.
Annotation as a service: assembly (think it will be on-board sequencers in the future), annotation (pipelines as a server), analysis (bespoke workflows). Plugging Taverna Workflow system.
http://www.taverna.org.uk/
Made workflows in Taverna, but looking at annotation as a cloud service, so have now tried to put this on the cloud as simply as possible (used AWS).
Didn’t want to send all 4 gig data (pay for what you transfer) – ways to split it up only upload parts you needed for analysis.
Boran dataset analysis in AWS (12.5 million SNPs) took 1hr 55 minutes and cost only $5!
“pipeline is the service”
A lot of this work recently published in PNAS http://www.taverna.org.uk/2011...
Interesting issues with data being in different zones in Amazon. Have to do cross zoning for Ensembl data (in West Coast US zone for some reason) – so cost and legal issues.

body: PT19: Gunhan Gulsoy - RINQ: Reference-based Indexing for Network Queries

comments.body: Network alignment are computationally hard problems.
Reference based indexing: A distance in 2D can be estimated by a reference point with lower and upper bound.
Multiple reference points will shrink the possible space, so distance might not be required to be measured directly.
Filter possible networks for comparison.
Lower bound calculation doable. Upper bound calculation more difficult, fails in some specific cases.
Creation of reference networks: should be small (local alignment is NP-complete), comprehensive, non-redundant.
For construction: Use an existing network from the a database C, modify the network by deletion and extension, comparison to existing networks R and include if too similar.
Results: KEGG gene reg network, used all > 15 nodes. Extracted 6 -8 nodes using random walks. QNet algorithm for comparison.
Q: Comprehensivity of the reference set? How comprehensive can a reference network be? A: No checking after training due to reduncy removal.
Q: Webserver or available implementation? A: Work as progress, query can take 5 hours. But code is available.
Q: How did you change parameters to achieve different accuracies? A: Different number of references.
Q: Different meanings of networks. Can this be considered in the alignment? A: Interesting question but level of abstraction does not allow currently. Could be expanded.
