body: TT13: Scott Markel,  Ruth Dunn - Analyzing Next Gen Sequencing Data with Pipeline Pilot

comments.body: Starts with a Biology > Sequence Analysis > FASTA sequence reader example.
Uses an example file with 10,000 sequences, FASTA format.
You can add a filter in a very clickably lovely way; this filter happens to ask whether the sequences have a paticular phrase (tyrosine kinase) in their description.
Next, align these.  Another component.  And then an alignment viewer.  Wow, it's so easy!
Clustalw component runs on linux in the background.

Easy access to commonly used reference genomes, or do de novo assemblies.  Works with Illumina, 454 and SOLiD.  BWA, Bowtie, mapreads to align.  Can detect SNPs, indels, CN variants.  Can do ChIP-seq and RNA-seq.  configured to run in parallel

Concept of sequence repository.  This is a way to manage the location of different kinds of files associated with next gen reads.  Repository is centered around the reference sequences.  In the background is a reference file with path information (repository.xml).  Store indexed FASTA files for refereence sequences.  BWA and bowtie do their own indexing; those are also saved.  SAMtools creates indexes.
Mapped reads are stored as sorted and indexed BAM files.  This is where we start to worry about size.  Could be 150-250 GB, and that is already indexed (30X human).

Features - SNPs, gene definitions.  Can compute features from reference sequences.  E.g., does Illumina have a GC bias?  Could go and find these in the reference sequence, and compare with coverage depth in the reads.  Features are stored as Tabix files (GFF3 but binary).  All file formats are from SAMtools.

Reason for using repository concept: help manage the data, and especially to be able to compare and contrast.  Could have several sets of reads, each with their own SNPs.  Wanted to allow chaining of components, e.g., only care about SNPs in or upstream of genes.
Now he goes back to the Pipeline Pilot application and builds things.

Reads in a FASTA file (E.coli); creates a sequence repository from this.  Could download reference sequence directly from NCBI or elsewhere, or use local file.  Then he adds features; he adds a GFF Reader module, then module "Add features to repository"

Now he adds some unmapped reads.  There is a component to generate simulated reads.  You might want to ask something like, what happens if I start from the same set of reads, and map them with two different mappers, and look at the resulting SNPs -- what's different?  Being able to simulate reads helps understand these differences -- e.g., pick a region around a SNP location, pick a read depth there, and then play around with the various algorithms for calling SNPs using that data.

He pulls in files he'd downloaded from the sequence read archive at NCBI.  Uses Bowtie short read mapper.  Uses 4 parallel threads.  It takes a couple of minutes to run; typically runs it on an HP cluster which takes about a minute.
The FASTQ Directory Reader allows you to start at a top-level directory and recurse.
If you want to filter -- you can preprocess your reads.  He shows a histogram of quality; this could be used to figure out where to trim if you want to do that ahead of time.

He brings in a Repository Query component now.  You can have various output types:  regions, reference sequences, reads, alignments, consensus.  He's going to look at region information.  Then he feeds the output into SAMtools variant calling for region.  He looks for both SNPs and indels; the output is added to the repository.

There are some pre-built examples - you can pick the organism you want to use.  Makes it easy for users to build repositories for reference sequences -- and then they don't have to ship all the sequence data with Pipeline Pilot.

So now he does a Repository Query, looking at one region of 5000 bp, and feeds the output into a Genome Viewer (Gbrowse2).  He selects genes, repeat regions, misc features and the SNPs just called.  Views it both showing depth and alignment.
Instead of specifying a region by bp, he could have done it by gene or other feature.
Now Ruth takes over the presentation...
Reasons to use PP: quick to make pipelines.  Flexible.  Easy to get started.  And... fun!
They have a booth, #25, Accelrys; can try out the software there.
She goes to the github crowdsource site - they had the E coli from an outbreak. I think the URL is https://github.com/ehec-ou...
You can use an ftp URL for the source of your data.

She compared Bowtie to BWA by just setting up two different pipes coming out of the same FASTQ reader.  She then called SNPs & indels on those different sets of mapped reads.  Pipeline pilot has a rich reporting set.  Can create PDFs, web-friendly docs.
Now she looks at particular genes of interest, and then chain the indels -- resulting in 1 out of 165 genes that has an indel.
The numbers of things moving along the pipes are shown so you can easily see the number of items you've found.
You can chain a bunch of different SNP callers to find the SNPs that are called by all of them.
Now she moves on to an example about quality.  She wanted to see if reads that map with one mismatch map differently than reads that map with multiple mismatches.
Ah - you can have variables in your protocol; for example, the name of the repository can be a variable (parameter).
You can run through a pipeline a specified number of times.
A protocol can become a component in another protocol.
Oh -- she is running through the protocol several times; each time with a different number of mismatches.  The output of each run is saved to a cache.
Then you make a cache reader, and write the output to a PDF reader.
There is a different graph for each of the mismatches.  You can see that reads that map with no mismatches are of a higher quality than reads that map with mismatches, just as you would expect.
PP makes updates to the components automatically, keeping them compatible with your "legacy" workflows.
Q: how practical is it to put in your own components, e.g., for visualization?  A:  viewers are trickier than command line programs.

System requirements...  Server SUSE11, Linux 32, Lunix64, Windows32, Windows64.  Nextgen collection is different:  Linux64 only.  Memory:  assembly requires lots of memory.  2B reads map in an hour with really good hardware.  You can control where files are stored.

body: PT17: Regev  Schweiger - Generative Probabilistic Models for Protein-Protein Interaction Networks – The Biclique Perspective

comments.body: Introduction by Rob Russell: The subject Networks were second in terms of submitted papers.
Protein don't work alone. TAP, Y2H interactomes in yeast. Datebases.
(Hairball)
Introduction to random graphs (Erdös-Renyi, geometric)
Degree distribution and clustering are not described by the above models. Alternatives are preferential attachment (PA) and duplication-divergence (DD).
How to test a graph model against a real world network. Compare distribution, network motifs, dense subgraphs are used.
Contribution: maximal bicliques. Bicliques are naturally related to the DD model
Introduced for web graphs, found in yeast interactome.
DIP set, plot all bicliques in heat map. Large range.
Generate many models, count maximal biclique count, compare to the real network, compare by sum of difference of logs.
Should become independent of parameters: scan the range of parameters and select the best for the real data.
DD is similar, larger cliques, outperforms PA. Seeds are important.
More simulations, best fit with inverse geometric random seed model. DD still outperforms PA.
Most of the bicliques are in the seed of the PA. In DD, its only 5.1%. Removing the seed bicliques shows stronger effects.
Q: Influence of abundance? A: Should be independent.
Q: Have you tested other measures? A: Yes (not presented). DD gives best results.
Q: Did you use only Y2H data? A: Yes, should be investigated more.
Q: Single large scale experiments rather then DIP? A: No.
Q&A (Rob Russell) Biological relevance? The DD network model makes more sense. [...]
Q: Inclusion of smaller cliques, overcounting. Term is not right as nodes are connected with one clique? A: Hmm, yes chould be named differently.
Q: Sequence similarity? A: Others have used this to come up with binding motives.
Q: Known quality of PPI - disassociativiy of hubs, other interaction network such as TFs? A: No, tested it a bit, few organisms have larger networks, TF networks are directed.
Q; Distribution of the counts, is the average a good measure? A: It's different for each model and set of parameters, variance rather small.
There's a  poster.

body: Keynote: Janet Thornton - The Evolution of Enzyme Mechanisms and Functional Diversity

comments.body: 10 year Keynote for ECCB
Special call-out to Elixir session today at 2:30 Hall F2 www.elixir-europe.org
Trying to understand life from molecules to systems
She's a "data junkie" -- everything depends on having your data properly organized and being able to extract information from it.
Most of our information is still at the parts level, with emerging data on interactions, reactions and pathways
at EBI - data doubling every 5 months 12 petabytes of storage currently
EBI contains presently 12 petabytes of data
We need to look not only at proteins but also at the small molecules, the metabolites.
Plants have way more metabolites than we do.
Cheminformatics is older but smaller than bioinformatics; largely confined to industry.  The tools are not freely available, with notable exceptions.
Differences between the proteome and the metabolome, e.g. no evolution and hierarchical structure of metabolites.
"Way back in the 90s" they were trying to define the reactome - the reactions necessary for life.
From the proteome and the metabolome to the reactome: How many reactions are necessary for life?
Enzymes are important part of biological molecular reasons
Enzymes are called by name and EC number.
Handling the reactions computationally is a challenge
Predicting enzyme function automatically: most powerful and most popular method is to recognize a homologue and transfer functional annotation.
EC numbers explained: they conform to the following format: C.SC.SSC.SN
The classification of enzymes are four-part: classes, subclasses, sub-subclass, serial number (typically the substrate)
where: C = Class, SC = Sub-class, SSC = Sub-subclass, SN = Serial number
EC numbers do not capture the mechanism of the enzyme.
Capture only the chemical level, no biological dependence such as co-factors
There is no one to one relationship between EC numbers and protein families
The reactome contains 4154 reactions
They wanted to build tools that would handle the actual chemistry.

There has been a lot of work in the past 10 years in tools to handle the chemistry.  Includes Kanehisa 2004, Gasteiger 2008, Aris-De-Sousa 2008, Schomburg 2010.  Unfortunately, most of the software isn't freely available, and only tackles part of the problem.
There is a huge literature on comparing small molecules to each other.  So that's well covered.

They also needed to map the atoms from each side of the equation to each other:  atom-atom mapping.  This works by matching the largest common moiety first, and iterating.  The Mesa (?) database of about 300 reactions is a gold standard to check the quality of the mapping.
You need to be able to compare reactions to each other - reaction similarity.

To describe the changes in the bonds that take place, you use the Dugundji-Ugi model -- you make a matrix showing the bonds for reactants and products; subtracting the matrices gives you the reaction matrix.
EC-BLAST created by Syed Asad Rahman; it allows you to compare reactions by bond similarity, reaction centre similarity or substrate structure similarity.
Chemicals have several fingerprints bond change, structure, stereo fingerprint
(See KillerApp talk I think Tues 11:45am)
CDK (Chemistry development kit) free software,
EC blast is here: http://www.ebi.ac.uk/thornto...
They looked into redefining the enzyme classification system.
Ligases in principle simple, most are 6.1s are amino-acyl-tRNA synthases
The EC-BLAST-server (URL above) is in closed beta.
Compared two reactions using Tanimoto coefficient
"This heatmap might look good to you, to me it looks fantastic!" Similarity between substrates is now close the EC classification. Differences might be based on the EC classification.
FunTree - Understanding enzyme families and evolution Poster #Z06
Why are some structures capable of so many different enzymatic functions? Which are the residues that led to change of function?
Examples from the Phosphatidylinositol-Phosphodiesterase-Superfamily, a multi-domain protein family.
They looked at the multi-domain architecture of the phosphatidylinositol-phosphodiesterase superfamily.  Adding new domains doesn't add enzyme function to members of this family.
One need to understand the evolution to better understand the EC classification
The tree constructed from structure has three main groups.   Branches of the tree are distinguished by differences in substrate, product, presence of a metal co-factor, or mechanism.

Matrix showing how frequently there are evolutionary changes within and between classes.  Evolution tends to create new enzymes within the same class, having the same mechanism but changing the substrate or product.
Most of the enzyme evol happening in the last sub class level

Question from the floor: is this an opportunity to abandon the EC classification method and move on to a better one?  Answer:  no.  The EC structure is very sensible.  Also, it is powerful because everybody uses it.  Also, in the first class we examined, it matches pretty well to the similarity measure we developed.
# Best keynote so far

Question:  sometimes you have a huge protein to carry out a single small reaction.  Have you noticed any clues to why this happens?  A: we have some thoughts related to protein function.  First, most proteins are multi-functional.  They interact with other proteins and do other sorts of things.  Secondly, some of the substrates are quite large.  We have a sort of domino theory of enzyme mechanism.  It's all to do with location.  (90% of enzymes work on exchange of protons.)  The enzymes are in the right place to catch the ball, the proton -- so you need exquisite locating of the substrates.

body: Keynote: Michael  Ashburner - From sequences to ontologies - adventures in informatics

comments.body: "The father of ontologies in biology" speaks without slides.
One well turned phrase is worth a thousand power points....

Almost 50 years after he started his undergrad in  Cambridge in geology to venture into paleontology. His developing interest in zoology was not matched by the respective department. Was asked to be the chairman of the department.
PhD on Drosophila in Cambridge, PostDoc at Caltech.
Stresse the importance of God-father for young scientists as role model etc.
No problems in funding in the 60s and early 70s.
Six month in Bruce Alberts lab. # not so easy to keep up with all the great people that Michael Ashburner worked with
No knowledge of repetitive DNA, formulation of the C-value paradox.
Work on Drosophila alcohol dehydrogenase spanning 20 years.

Sequencing of ADH of 4 species using radionucleotides led to a PhD and a Nature paper. Almost no software available, major hardware incompatibility. Only one ARPAnet node in Europe at the University London.
Initially 120 baud bandwidth.
1983, first version of the EMBL database, came on magnetic tape 60kB. First thing: Print and read annotations.
at that time size is 60kb
No relational integrity, lots of integrity. Moaning about it led to a position on the advisory board.
Promoter of the establishment of the EBI at the Cambridge site. No genomics at the EMBL in the 80s. Raised 30 M GPB to convince the EMBL council.
Gopher!
Flybase establishment. Built in Sybase, output in files, distribution via Gopher. Later, contact with Amos Bairoch and Expasy led to use of a webserver.
AceDB memories.
Hierarchical, structured language use in FlyBase, extension to other model organisms.
Presented in 1997 at the ISMB in Greece.
Whitepaper for the 1998 in Montreal. Lot's of resistance from various groups.
Gene Ontology sealed in 1999, support from the yeast and mouse databases.
Incyte had a patent on controlled vocabulary. (Utter not reproducable here)
Drosophila genome project, finalized in 6 month, genome annotation jamboree.

body: PT46: Julia Sivriver - An Integrative Clustering and Modeling Algorithm for Dynamical Gene Expression Data

comments.body: Transcriptional response with wide dynamical range. Is it enough to only know the TFs? No, need to know the answer times etc. Cannot ask the genes, yield only expression at one point.

How to come to the dynamical response? Fitting to a  model. Early models by Chechik et al.  JCB, 2009 had 7 parameters (peak height, onset and offset rates etc), can be learned by conjugate gradient descent.
Too few time points lead to overfitting.
We can cluster time course data as not every gene has its own dynamical prototype. Can work on the clusters for parameter learning. Traditional distance measures don't work well.
Use the clusters to extract dynamical prototypes to get model parameters, then use the model for cluster. Start with naive k-means, iterate until satisfaction.
Fitting to priors (prototypes), generate model and paramters.
Validation by synthetic data, add noise to expression data. Compare to k-means using euclidian and correlation distance. Use mutual information for assessment, works comparable.
Model avoids overfitting, median fit error compared to Chechik et al.
Case study: response to LPS and PolyIC in mice, Amit et al , Science 2009, 24h study. Chose 1000 genes repressed or induced in the study, used both stimuli.
Several clusters, corresponding to early response, stimuli, motifs (every clusters show at least one motif overrepresented)
Sets are characterized by parameters.
A general approach for analyzing time course data. # nice method and talk
Q: Do you think number of clusters change? A: No, is fixed from beginning.Can use iterative approach if clusters are very similar.
Q/A: Simulated data, number of clusters  was fixed.
Q/A: Dependence on starting conditions, use different starting positions.

body: PT44: Paweł P. Łabaj - Characterization and improvement of RNA-Seq precision in quantitative transcript expression profiling

comments.body: Low reproducability with next generation sequencing of transcript expression.
More complex algorithms correct for expected read counts and many other known biases.
Use of TopHat and CuffLink (gene models and transcription levels) improve much over simple models relying on unique hits.
Summary due to WLAN issues: Comparison of combinations of popular tools
Q: For microarray you need genes... A: Yes, but we can use the RNA-Seq. Q: How much do you gain from MA to RNA-Seq? Q: Large numbers unresolved but not possible to say at this stage.
Q: Isn't RNA-Seq a curse for bioinformatics. You need 100 M reads to be comparable to an Affy platform. A: Yes, at least in higher eukaryotes. Combination of technologies will yield improvements.
Q: Comparison RPKM and expression? A: No, wanted to check the tools that are popular.

body: HL35: Magnus Rattray - Model-based method for transcription factor target identification with limited data

comments.body: Question of which F combinations are most likel given evidence from temporal data? Use of fitting regulation models to address this
Fitting a single TF linear activation model  (concentraton based) - goal is to fit genome wide
Challenges - model parameters unknown ; few time points; noisy data; "open" system because of f(t) - concentration of tf. Their solution: can model f(t) as Gaussian process
examples of approach from Honkela et al PNAS 2010
interesting discussion on how to evaluate using chIP-seq data
Discussion of new extensions - multiple TF
examination of enrichment of pairs (TF-target link and TF-TF)
noted that TF activated by signalling can be modelled as latent
tigre bioconductor package
could incorporate chIP-seq data for priors (with-held here for evaluation purposes)
Q: could you adapt model to focus on TF that spike - influence behavior of other TF quickly? A: could adapt via binary switches

comments.body: Collaboration with Bipolar Genome Study (BiGS) Consortium

Q: could you use initial results from GWAS to weight secondary analysis? A: issue of bias if intiail results are false positives - could be used in 2 stage design with independent data if wanted to apply ouside of intended secondary analysis use case
Q: issue of filtering for MAF for pairs? A: QA/QC was done for individual SNPs; More of issue for 3 or more SNPs - could be added as additional filter

Q: Curious about results for use of hubs in narrowing search space? A: Could be that not as critical for BP. More likely that search space is larger given how highly connected they are and algorithm can get "stuck"

body: Keynote: Luis Serrano - M pneumoniae (Towards a full quantitive understanding of a free-living system)

comments.body: Fully understanding of Micoplasma pneumoniae -
Can we successfully analyze and integrate large number of data types in order to predict changes in system in face of any perturbation? Use case: M pneumoniae
It contains 689 ORFs + 44 RNSs , 10TFs,  kinases and one phosphatase
10 TF ( classical) 2 kinases, 1 phosphatase, full chemical signaling repertoire
EM tomography used to get the cytoskeleton
Related papers from this work: Yus et al 2009; Güell et al 2009
Metabolome - it was difficult to draw the metabolic network, mined last 20years of literature and final network contains 129 enzymes, 140 genes
Strong argument that structural analysis is key
Modeled using flux balance analysis (FBA)

Motabolomics analysis done using MS and NMR  ... developed complete validated map, but missing parameters for reactions, regulatory loops, effect of post translational modifications, enzymes for reactions,
Transcriptome, initially used microarrays, then time-dependent tilling array, then did single strand sequencing
Expression profiling:  ncRNA everywhere.  expression appears to decay along the operon - "staircase behavior"
take home points non-coding RNA abundant; staircase behaviour of operons (steps coincide with end of gene in operon) ? of how this is regulated.
more than 1 promoter for one operon seems common
There is a whole huge world of translational regulation, and we "don't have a clue"
suggestion to replace operon model
Cool - there are different RNA polymerase complexes that recognize different operon-start locations; each one also recognizes particular stop signals, and so each may transcribe a different operon.
how to explain complexity with so few tf?
other proteins can act as TF
possible role of noncoding
found new putative RNA/DNA binding proteins
Tiny RNAs accurately mark the transcription start sites of genes, about 40 bases long.  Have also been found in eukaryotes.  Don't know function.
Summary - transcriptional complexity in M. pneumoniae could be explained by new TFs, ncRNA, tiny RNAs, new RNA/DNA binding proteins, etc.
Missing - who regulates the TFs and DNA binding proteins
Analysis of protein complexes - Sebestian Kuhner et al Science 326, 1235 (2009)
Electron tomography: can visualize large complexes.  Allows you to count the number of complexes per cell.
Full quantification of proteins and transcripts to get copies per cell, with half-life modeling, and taking into consideration point in growth curve.  From this, create full computer model.
Statistically more abundant proteins are more essential like Ecoli
Some mRNAs present at (way) less than 1 copy per cell.
Poor correlation between mRNA and proteins (~0.5)
low copy  number of noise - low translation efficiency and long protein half-life eliminates noise
150 ribosomes, 400 promoters, 140 RNA polymerase
There are probably different ribosomes, with different subunit compositions.
protein/volume ratio is a magic number - a universal constant:  200 g/l.  This is true for 3 bacteria -- is it true for human?
They have observed post-translational modifications, but we don't yet know how they are placed, or their function.
It's tough to convince students and post-docs to dive into the badly needed research on one or a few proteins when omics experiments are so much faster and often publishable in better journals.

body: SS05:  Richard I. Kitney - Special session on synthetic biology:  System Design Challenges

comments.body: The aim of synthetic biology is to build applications from BioParts.  The parts encode biological functions and are made from synthetically designed DNA.
Devices are made from a collection of parts, and encode human-defined functions like logic gates.
Systems are made from devices and carry out tasks like counting or control.
Design cycle:  specifications --> design --> modeling --> implementation --> testing/validation --> specification
They do small-scale assembly of parts and devices in-house.  Large scale assembly of parts and devices happens at gene synthesis companies, like Gene Arts in Germany.
Applications in various industries:  healthcare, pharma, biofuels, agroscience.
They have an integrated BioCAD and modeling suite:  SynBIS
There are four levels in the modeling:  interface, communication (XML), application, and database.
Application example:  biosensor design.  Detection of medically problematic pathogenic biofilms.
Solution is to detect a protein with a three-stage device:  detector, amplifier and indicator.
Can convert the description of device behavior into standard systems diagrams and equations; can simulate device behavior.
Second example:  logic AND gate.  Can be used to measure two carbon sources, presence of two organisms, etc.

body: SS05 Part B:  Ron Weiss - Special session on synthetic biology:  from parts to modules in therapeutic systems

comments.body: Ron Weiss is from MIT.  15 years ago as a computer scientist got interested in programming biology the way we program computers.
How could we use directed evolution?
Applications:  biomedical, bioenergy, environmental

Library of parts & devices includes regulation, gene activity, RNAi, protein-protein interactions.  Cell-cell communication.  Reporters (e.g., color fluorescence).  Interface wtih cell and environment.
The toolbox of parts is expanding rapidly.
Modules implemented in Weiss lab:  ultrasensitive switch (transcriptional cascade; output is NOT-NOT of input).  Going for digital logic.  The output becomes more step-like.
Noisy biological components can be used to create robust digital systems.
Another module from Weiss lab:  pulse generator.  Cells engineered to send AHL to antoher cell; resulting in GFP pulse.
Ring-like spatial patterns is another example, across multiple cells.  Can express fluor protein if have medium level of signaling protein.
Working on things like differentiating embryonic stem cells on demand.

Working on automating the process, where there is a high level description from a human, and then the formal description can be um implemented automatically.  Compiler brings it down to genetic networks, sends assembly instructions to a robot and puts into cells.
Then iterate over design.
Example of high level spec:  (yellow (not (cyan (AHL)))).  [yay - LISP!]  This means if AHL is high, produce Cyan else produce Yellow.
He shows how that gets compiled down into available parts, and then into instructions for the robot for assembly.
3 months from now expect to have full system working.
The BioCompiler can take any combinatorial logic function and implement it.
They can also implement state and spatial patterns.  Described not at level of individual cells but rather at the level of cell community.
The circuit compiled from a spatial description is identical to what was designed in the lab by hand.
Now working on the notion of transient behavior.
Example:  cancer therapy -- decipher the transcriptome.
Problem:  most existing cancer therapies not specific enough; result in significant collateral damage.
Looking at a single cell surface receptor is not sufficient to identify cancer cells.  They want to develop a therapy that evaluates internal cell state using combinatorial logic.
They use an RNAi based logic circuit.  A smart virus infects a cell, computes whether the transcriptome is indicative of cancer and then destroys the cell.
Example:  HeLa cell classifier (with Benenson lab)
Program:  HeLa = miR-21 and (miR=17 + miR-30a) and not miR-141 and not miR-142 and not miR-146.
Gotta say, this stuff is real scary.
he shows a HeLa-Low sensor - a part that is on when the miRNA is low.
AND gate of multiple sensors:  just put the recognition sequences along the gene.
A "high" sensor is a "not not" of the input.  So you have an activator and a repressor; the miR inhibits both...  I'll just believe this.
Two combine two sensors, you combine their output.  They have the same transcription factors but different regions that sense miRs.  He shows full circuit for the original logical expression.
They tested this circuit with the 32 different input combinations.  Shows that output (RFP) is high only when the have the particular input they want.
OMG - tested on 7 different cell lines, and see strong response only for HeLa and not the other cancer cell lines.  Even though didn't specifically engineer it to not detect these other cell types.
Since then, optimized the circuit further, and got a 25-fold difference between HeLa and next best match.
Tested for killing efficiency.
New example - artificial tissue homeostasis for beta cells, diabetes application.
In diabetes type I, the auto-immune response slowly kills insulin-producing pancreatic beta cells.
Want to maintain the population level of beta cells using auto-regulated differentiation of ES cells that counter-balances the auto-immune attacks.
This is a huge system with 22 components; not yet done.  Trying to understand issues with such a complex system. Biggest system published to date has 6 parts.
Some results -- have created a module to differentiate ES cells to cells with beta-like properties.  Can produce insulin.
Also have cell-cell communication, and a toggle switch.  If decide need to become beta cells, need to remember that decision.
Shows program for the whole thing.
Shows system architecture created by hand.   Includes stem cell and beta cell population control units.  Then AND gate going into differentiation decision.

In simulation, see some cases with oscillation (not ideal).  Version 2 was attempt to remove the oscillations.  Noticed long feedback delay ... added fast toggle switch so that the commitment decision is fed back even before differentiation happens.
...   integrated noise ...  Large fluctuations result...
Shows simulation; having trouble maintaining steady levels in the context of noise.  Next revision includes using noise to make a more robust system.
Oscillators rather quickly go out of phase; they use these bad oscillators to generate useful noise to break symmetry in the system.
Simulations show that this works to obtain steady levels.
Often in system design you optimize the modules first.  Um, I think he is saying that you simulate the system to see how module characteristics affect system performance?
He shows the full homeostasis gene network and talks about how individual modules have been successfully implemented.
Now the challenge is systems integration.
In summary, soon we will have end-to-end, high-level-design to automated DNA assembly
In future want better understanding of circuit interaction with cellular context, and predictive design and construction of large circuits.
My summary:  Wow.  just wow.  And, still, scary.

Q:  cells are so complicated and the circuits are so complex.  How can these designed circuits possibly work in real cell systems?  A:  we can already predict what a population of cells will do, with small modules.  Optimistic about tackling larger circuits, using systems built out of orthogonal parts with minimal interaction with cell systems.

body: SS05 Part C.  Chris Voigt (presented by Brit (?)):  Expanding the genetic language to program cells.

comments.body: Lab is moving from UCSF to MIT.
She'll talk about 3 projects in the lab.
First, introduction -- cells can be programmed to carry out a variety of tasks.
DNA is synthesized and transformed into host cell.

Have engineered E coli to sense light, carry out computing.  Engineered bacteria to carry out complex image processing task - edge detection.  Made remote-controlled bacteria to control bacterial chemotaxis.  In absence of Ara, swim toward some gradient; in presence, swim toward something else.
Three components:  sensors, circuits, actuators.  Communication between components via changes in gene expression.
The program can get large:  tens of kilobases of DNA.
Developing a genetic compiler.  Given a desired truth table, select genetic parts and assemble them into the final circuit topology, and then DNA sequence.
Currently don't have very many robust parts for the circuit library, and that's the topic of the rest of the talk.
She's been working on identifying additional parts.  She'll also talk about making the parts more reliable.  She'll finish by talking about the largest part they've built.
She screened a library of 73 repressors, each a homolog of Tet repressor.  Output was a reporter containing the LmrA operator.  So they use this to identify repressor-operator pairs.
Can connect circuits to each other.  Can connect a gate to a sensor, etc.  Need the intrinsic transfer function of the gate to not change as a function of genetic context.
Someone else in the lab looked into this.
Optimized (removed genetic-context-specific variability) using spacer sequences.
AND gates, with readout being secretion from cell.  Built using parts from various organisms.
Achieve independence or orthogonality of different gates -- transcription factor only binds this one promoter and so on.  Undesirable interactions removed by directed evolution.
Promoter engineering to enhance dynamic range.
Shows 4-input AND gate comprised of 11 orthogonal regulators.  4 are the sensors, and a single RFP output.  It works.
Total size is 21kb; on 3 distinct plasmids.
Hope to identify additional orthogonal regulators.  Have identified about 25 previously unidentified orghogonal regulators.  Screening hundreds obtained by synthesis.

body: SS05 Part D:  C. Forbes Dewer, Jr - Bioinformatics for synthetic biology: managing the 'BRICKS' of synthetic biology

comments.body: From MIT.
Standardizing:  each component consists of a circular vector of dsDNA with the component regulatory sequence, flanked by EcoRI and XbaI sites.
Combine to get the logic you want.
Reference:  Basu et al, Nature 434, 2005.

iGEM program brings together students and labs to tackle synthetic biology problems, creating community.  Last year >1000 people.  This year, 3 regional conferences with a final iGEM conference at MIT.  All of the constructs the teams develop go into an open repository.
Learning from the past - situations where there were multiple labs developing individual solutions, and then wanting to combine solutions.

Example:  DICOM (Digital Image COmmunication in Medicine).  Started in mid-1980s.  Unsuccessful.  Attempt to break the monopoly of Siemens, GE, other company on equipment.  It wasn't until 1993 that there was an international standard adopted.  By 1998-9, that standard covered all of the individual areas of medical informatics.

A problem that came up:  this consensus on the standard had to be hammered out in committees and agreed to.  The vocabulary was totally controlled.  That takes a lot of time and can become politicized.
As an example:  Take microscope image, make object definition as had been done with medical imaging.
For example, in a microscope, you have an objective, you have filters - and all this information must accompany the image.
Unfortunately, took this definition to a lab at Harvard Medical School.  But they had different definitions.  To make further progress, had to reconcile the semantics.

It is possible to avoid this problem or get by it, by using communication pipes between the different datasets.  Don't get trapped in semantic fights; agree to use lists of synonyms.  Re-use the work of others.  Use machine-parsable information.  Create ontologies.  Reference existing curated collections.
SBOL = Synthetic Biology Open Language
Clotho - idea of setting up the equivalent of cloud computing.  Site on the web - don't have to know the details of how the functionality works for these synth bio modules.
BioPAX ontology.  Demir et al Nature Biotech 28:935
